Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, §28 and c. 209C, §20, Plaintiff **Jessica Sullivan** respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody order entered on **September 15, 2021**, in the above-entitled matter.

c. 209C, \u00a720.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, §28 and c. 209C, §20, Plaintiff **Jessica Sullivan** respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody order entered on **September 15, 2021**, in the above-entitled matter.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a728.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 208, §28**, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody judgment upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a720.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 208, §28** (modification of judgments for custody and support of minor children), **M.G.L. c. 209C, §20**, and **M.G.L. c. 215, §6**.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a76.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 208, §28** (modification of judgments for custody and support of minor children), **M.G.L. c. 209C, §20**, and **M.G.L. c. 215, §6**.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a728A.proposition: The Court may impose appropriate **conditions or supervised parenting time** under **M.G.L. c. 208, §28A**, and **Mass. Prob. Ct. Standing Order 1‑06**, to safeguard a child’s welfare during transitions.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (200.proposition: See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (2003) (court must determine whether changed circumstances affect child’s welfare); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006) (trial courts have broad discretion to modify custody when the child’s safety and welfare are implicated).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (200.support_reasoning: Custody of Kali is a first-instance custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, §10(a), not a modification proceeding. The court discusses the best-interests standard, the statutory factors, and the importance of stability, but it does not adopt or apply a ‘changed circumstances’ test, nor does it state that a court must determine whether changed circumstances affect the child’s welfare as a prerequisite to altering custody. The cited pages focus on weighing best-interests factors, not on a modification/changed-circumstances framework.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (200.relevant_excerpt: “The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child… In most cases, however, if the child has been living with one parent for some time, the child’s needs are being adequately met under that parent’s care, and that parent is capable of continuing to care for the child, it is not in the child’s best interests to disrupt that successful arrangement.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (2003) (court must determine whether changed circumstances affect child’s welfare); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006) (trial courts have broad discretion to modify custody when the child’s safety and welfare are implicated).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: The cited pages of Mason v. Coleman address the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth when parents share joint physical and legal custody, and the associated ‘best interests of the child’ analysis. They do not state or discuss that trial courts have broad discretion to modify custody when the child’s safety and welfare are implicated; the focus is on authorizing or denying removal, not on the scope of discretion to modify custody arrangements. Thus, using Mason as authority for a broad discretion-to-modify-custody proposition misstates its holding.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion. White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. 64, 68 (2001), quoting Boulter-Hedley v. Boulter, 429 Mass. 808, 811 (1999). … From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol. … Her findings regarding the situation are warranted by the evidence and, based on them, her conclusion that removal is not in the children’s best interests is not an abuse of discretion.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: In **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985), the Supreme Judicial Court emphasized that the “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody modifications.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does state that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern and that removal must be in the child’s best interests. However, it does not say that the best-interests standard governs all custody modifications generally; rather, it discusses best interests specifically in the context of initial custody determination and removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30. The proposition overreads the case by extending its language to all custody modifications, which Yannas does not do at the cited page.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt:
“The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

“Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 260 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 260 (2001) holds that deterioration in a parent’s conduct or lifestyle may constitute a material change warranting modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a relocation request plus a court-imposed temporary change in custody constitute a material and substantial change under G.L. c. 208, § 28; it concludes they do not. The court emphasizes that there was no change in circumstances after the divorce that warranted modifying custody and notes that the mother remained a loving and appropriate caretaker. It does not discuss any deterioration in a parent’s conduct or lifestyle as a basis for modification, nor does it state that such deterioration can constitute a material change.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker.”

White v. White, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1.raw_text: White v. White, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1996)
White v. White, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1.proposition: The Court in **White v. White**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1996) recognized that evidence of habitual substance abuse and its impact on the child’s environment justifies altering custodial arrangements.
White v. White, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns procedural and evidentiary error in conducting a private, unrecorded-style interview of an adult witness in a custody/visitation dispute, focused on alleged sexual abuse and due process, not on habitual substance abuse or its impact on the child’s environment. Nowhere does the court discuss substance abuse as a factor or hold that such evidence justifies altering custodial arrangements. The case thus does not establish or recognize the specific legal principle claimed in the proposition.
White v. White, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 132 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Testimony and evidence at trial convince me that the [father] has been a perpetrator of sexual abuse to his younger (age 7) child [Margaret] .... Testimony by the older daughter [Rebecca] (age 22), while not dispositive, tended to support the allegations of sexual abuse. … It is clear that the judge’s findings on custody and visitation rights were tainted by the private session… The error of holding the private session was so substantial that it warrants a new trial on the issues of custody and visitation.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544 (2.proposition: **Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540, 544 (2010) instructs that a parenting plan should protect the child from exposure to unsafe or unstable conditions, even where the parent previously was fit.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544 (2.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the mother’s right, as the sole legal parent of a nonmarital child, to relocate without court or putative father permission before paternity is established. It discusses stability in terms of not unnecessarily disturbing an existing parenting arrangement, but it does not instruct that a parenting plan must protect a child from exposure to unsafe or unstable conditions, nor does it address modifying parenting plans where a previously fit parent becomes unsafe or unstable. Thus the proposition overstates and mischaracterizes what Smith v. McDonald holds.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544 (2.relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...')."

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.proposition: In **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012), the Court reiterated that the Family Court's paramount duty is to act with the child’s welfare paramount over competing parental interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames custody determinations in terms of the child’s best interests and cites precedent that the child’s welfare is paramount, not parental claims. In discussing custody, the court emphasizes that judges must weigh all relevant factors to determine what is best for the child and notes that custody is not a vehicle to punish a parent, but to serve the child's welfare. This aligns with the proposition that the Family Court’s paramount duty is to put the child’s welfare above competing parental interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’’… The judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question. … [C]ustody proceedings were not a vehicle to punish the mother’s behavior. Here, the judge’s assessment of Rose’s behavior was in the context of determining with which parent it was in Jill’s best interest to live.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: See also **Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (unreported changes in a parent’s stability warranted modification); **Adoption of Cadence**, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 452 (2012) (court may consider patterns of neglect or impaired parenting capacity); **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 405–06 (1981) (the court may order limitations on visitation to ensure a child’s safety).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any unreported changes in a parent’s stability, patterns of neglect or impaired parenting capacity, or limitations on visitation. Instead, it addresses the need for proper best‑interests findings under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and rejects using custody as a means to punish a parent for misconduct unrelated to the child’s welfare. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific propositions for which it is being cited.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 556 n.5 (1980). The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child…. The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

Adoption of Cadence, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 4.raw_text: Adoption of Cadence, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 452 (2012)
Adoption of Cadence, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: See also **Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (unreported changes in a parent’s stability warranted modification); **Adoption of Cadence**, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 452 (2012) (court may consider patterns of neglect or impaired parenting capacity); **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 405–06 (1981) (the court may order limitations on visitation to ensure a child’s safety).
Adoption of Cadence, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 4.case_name: Verizon New England Inc. v. Board of Assessors of Boston
Adoption of Cadence, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 4.support_reasoning: The proposition attributes to Adoption of Cadence the rule that a court may consider patterns of neglect or impaired parenting capacity, in the context of custody/visitation and child safety. The opinion text provided is not Adoption of Cadence at all, but a tax case involving Verizon and municipal assessors about the taxation of poles, wires, and construction work in progress. It does not address family law, parenting capacity, neglect, or visitation, and therefore cannot support the claimed proposition.
Adoption of Cadence, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 4.relevant_excerpt: Verizon New England Inc. (Verizon) appeals from a decision of the Appellate Tax Board (board) concluding that poles and wires (which the parties refer to as “aerial plant”) erected on public ways, as well as construction work in progress (CWIP), are subject to taxation by the cities of Boston and Newton for fiscal year (FY) 2003 through FY 2009. For the reasons that follow, we vacate the board’s order.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 405–06 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: See also **Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (unreported changes in a parent’s stability warranted modification); **Adoption of Cadence**, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 452 (2012) (court may consider patterns of neglect or impaired parenting capacity); **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 405–06 (1981) (the court may order limitations on visitation to ensure a child’s safety).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly addresses the trial judge’s authority to limit a noncustodial parent’s visitation and affirms a reduction in the father’s visitation time based on the children’s best interests and concerns about their welfare (including reference to “incidents inconsistent with the best interests of the children”). The court expressly recognizes that promoting the child’s best interests may require limiting a parent’s liberties, thereby supporting the proposition that a court may order visitation limitations to ensure a child’s safety and welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he ‘best interests’ of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ … We do not think it would serve any useful purpose to recount portions of the evidence from which the judge could reasonably have determined that incidents inconsistent with the best interests of the children … occurred during certain extended periods when the husband was exercising his visitation rights….”}
